William B. Anderson's letter dated July 11, 1862 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on both sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 12.5 inches tall (20 x 32 cm). The paper is not ruled as are others in this collection. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded twice crosswise and not lengthwise, leaving a 5 inch middle section without foldes. This may or may not illustrate the size of the envelope. At this writing, the ink appears brown and the paper off-white (cream). A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper lefthand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the mark is indistinct, its shape closely matches that of a distinct, similarly sized and positioned printer's mark on a letter dated July 18, 1863, which reads "OWEN & HURLBUT SO. LEE MASS" (see illustrations). Texture? Stiffness? Watermarks? I will have to visit the RBML.

projectDesc.p: William B. Anderson’s letter written on 11 July 1862 to his wife, Mary Louisa shares many elements with those letters in the collection of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. The letters offer readers insight into the life world of the letter writer and recipient. It is significant that W. B. Anderson is not a well-know historical figure and that he was not public or remarkable in his time. Thus, this collection is rich with historical information. The letters reveal details surrounding everyday life on the Ohio River circa 1862 – 1864 (Hewitt). Moreover, with close attention to the collection we can see the use of historical conventions of correspondence, the effects of the Civil War on families and the use of letters as communication between family members separated for long periods.

Though they were not written by a ‘remarkable’ figure, the letters are unique in that they defy strict characterization as familial letters or as business letters. Rather, they are familial in that they contain (often one-sided), personal dialogue between family members and they are relevant to the family’s business prospects in that Anderson communicates with Mary Louisa about the investments for which she is responsible in his absence (Hewitt). The letter of 11 July 1862 is also distinctive within this unique collection. Of special interest is the content that is revelatory of rules of letter writing, the familial and business inquiries, and what the letter explains about the riverboat industry. Anderson’s writing style shows that he is educated in that he attempts to follow letter etiquette of the time (Hewitt). He apologizes and asks his wife to “excuse bad writing” presumably because he is rushed and is apologetic that he cannot write in proper form. A unique feature of this letter is found in the multiple closings and signatures. Each time he signs off, he follows similar rules. Although obviously rushed, he is sure to sign his name after each addition. Moreover, it seems he is evaluating his wife’s letter writing and seems to suggest that she is following conventions inadequately. He imagines her days as much more conducive to proper letter writing than are his, and seems to see her as somewhat of an inadequate letter writer. It is interesting to note that he sends her envelops for her letters. Why this is so may offer insight to federal postal operations (Hewitt).

Again, the letters on a whole include both familial and business issues and the letter of 11 July 1862 is no exception. Anderson inquires about two of the children (they had a total of five) and asks about the maid, giving insight into the household economy. He also asks his wife about the prospects of Corn Plater[?] & Co. which is presumably one of the companies with which Mary Louisa does business. Anderson explains a bit about his work at hand on the riverboat. His success and travels are dependent on the “the prospect of water” and on the speed with which he can transport goods. He tells her that, “our prospects are poor” but that if his boat is able to beat the Fanny McBurnie[?] to the dock at Murraysville, they will be benefited materially.
BoatSpeed.mov
Professor Hewitt on Boat Speed
Thus, this letter shows that speed was indeed a dynamic factor of success in the riverboat trade (Hewitt).

The archival life of this collection as a whole, along with the letter of 11 July 1862, continues. Although the letters cannot be viewed in physical form unless one travels to The Ohio State University, with the availability of the letters online they will be of interest to postal historians, business historians and to scholars interested in nineteenth century penmanship and linguistic conventions.
Hewitt, Elizabeth. Lecture to English 569C, Digital Media and English Studies. The Ohio State University. 6 Apr. 2006.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 11 July 1862.

div1.p: Anderson tells his wife that his boat will attempt to beat another riverboat to Murraysville, WV. He explains that his sleep has been restless, inquires about their two sons and asks her to write more and to write back regarding business prospects. He is rushed, and signs off three times.
Previous letter 27 June 1862 Next letter 28 July 1862.

I have but a moment to
drop you a line we are about to leave
here it is now 1 Oclock and we are
anxious to leave ahead of the Fanny M Burny 3
for by doing so we Can beat her to Mays=
=ville4 and by so doing will be benefitted
Materially our prospects are poor & we can
not count on making much this trip but
are bound to Keep the Boat moving I
Telegraphed to Pitt 5today to see what the
prospect of water was & have not got an
Answer to my dispatch yet, I am extremely
Anxious to get home and will go as soon
as water & other circumstances will permit
last night was the worst night I ever attempted
to put in, I never saw the like of the mosquitoes
I tried to Sleep in my room & Failed and then
failed and tried in the recess at the stern and
failed then also & then in the Boiler deck &
from that to the hurricane deck & still failed
and John6 and I started up town and got a
good room at the spence house7 and slept from
1 to 5 oclock which is the best sleep I have
had for a week. You would not think that
the mosquitoes could be as large and plentifull as
they are John8 says that they are worse than
they were at California 9. Enough of Complaints
I think you might string out your letters
a little longer as you have a good and cool
place to write and I have not, give my love
to the children and yourself I am in a hurry
Excuse bad writing

Write to me and let me know how
old man Walsh11 is Coming on also what
the prospects of Corn Potatoes &C.12 are
also what you and the Maid13 have been
doing and how she tured out is Willy14
at school & has John 15got stout
I am interrupted by Jo16 & others and must
stop so good by

PS be sure to write as before
I enclosed an Envellop in Yesterdays
letter

div1.head: Notes
div1.note:
1. The "2" is somewhat unclear. It resembles a "4". However, later in the letter, the author tells his wife to "be sure to write as before" and that he has "enclosed an envelope in yesterday's letter. The day before (Friday) July 11, 1962 would have been a Thursday, whereas the day before (Monday) July 11, 1964 would have been a Sunday. Assuming the author literally enclosed and mailed a letter containing an envelope, the date must be 1962 as he could not have sent mail out on Sunday.
Dateline: Pitts Cin July 11 / 62 (this "2" resembles the author's "4"s)
Click here to view dateline

2. Mary Louisa Fischgens (1837-1911) and William B. Anderson (1822-1897) married September 15, 1853 in Cincinnati, Ohio. History of Allegheny County, Pennsylvania (1889), 298. According to the the Jamie Danker E-mail, both are buried in the Allegheny Cemetery. Also, in light of this email, not all of the information found in History of Allegheny County, Pennsylvania (1889), is correct.

3.The author is most definitely referring to a riverboat. Although the writing is unclear, he may be naming the Fanny McBurnie. If so, he has misspelled the name by replacing the ‘ie’ with a ‘y’, writing M. Burny. I found no record of a boat that went by such a spelling. However, the Fanny McBurnie seems to have existed according to www.steamboats.org.

4. City in what is now West Virginia named after Elijah Murray, who opened a boatyard there in 1838, after moving from Steubenville, Ohio. Steubenville, OH and Murraysville, WV are located along the Ohio River. Murraysville is located approximately halfway between Cincinatti, OH (where the author is located whilst writing this letter) and Pittsburgh, PA (the author’s hometown) if one follows the distance of the Ohio River. W. B. Anderson had Glide No. 2 built in Murraysville in 1862 after the government seized and bought Glide No. 1. He used Glide No. 2 to carry supplies from Cincinnati to Nashville, Tennessee, until the government took charge of, and then bought the boat. History of Allegheny County, 298. and Ohio History (Winter-Spring 2004, 18-30).
7. Most probably a hotel or inn located in Cincinnati, Ohio.
9. State located on the West coast of the United States.
10. William B. Anderson (1822-1897). History of Allegheny County, 298.
11. Old man Walsh is unidentified, though he probably lived in Pittsburgh near the Anderson homestead.

12. I was unable to find any information on this company, but can state that it makes sense that one of the family's buisness interests would be in a grain company. I say this because of their location in the United States Midwest on the Ohio river were riverboats could transport grains.

14. William Y. Anderson (1855-1890). Product of Anderson’s marriage to Mary Louisa Fischgens. He Married Nancy C. McKinely. He resided in Shoustown, Pa. He died of typhoid in PA, leaving a widow and two children. He is buried in Allegheny Cemetery. He left a widow and two young children. History of Allegheny County, 298. and the Jamie Danker E-mail.

15. John L. Anderson (1859-1922). Product of Anderson’s first marriage to Mary Louisa Fischgens. Resided at the homestead. Wounded in Spottsylvania, Va., May 14, 1864, while serving the sixty-second Pennsylvania volunteers from Antietam to Appomattox. He survived typhoid in 1890. He never married. He is buried in the Allegheny Cemetery. History of Allegheny County, 298.
